en: Interview with Jeff Rouse, volunteer with Samaritan's Purse, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Rouse discusses his background with Samaritan's Purse before detailing the efforts of the organization in Gatlinburg after the wildfires. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "All of a sudden, one of the team members found this airplane, and it was just like finding a long lost piece of gold or something. It was just amazing that they were so excited because that was some memory of their dad."

Interview with Jeff Rouse, volunteer with Samaritan's Purse, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Rouse discusses his background with Samaritan's Purse before detailing the efforts of the organization in Gatlinburg after the wildfires. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "All of a sudden, one of the team members found this airplane, and it was just like finding a long lost piece of gold or something. It was just amazing that they were so excited because that was some memory of their dad."

Would you state your name and tell us about yourself?
Can you tell us about the mission of Samaritan's Purse and what drew you to them?
What were some of the other deployments like with Samaritan's Purse?
When did you first get the call about heading to Gatlinburg and when did you first hear about the fire?
What are the expectations of the volunteers? What are you orienting them to?
Are the volunteers usually first timers or veterans?
How do the wildfire victims sign up to be recepients of Samaritan's Purse?
As part of the site leadership team, what does that entail?
Can you talk about your experiences going out and meeting these  families from the Gatlinburg fire?
From your expertise in construction, when you were going to these homes, did you ever think about how the houses could be better constructed for fire prevention?
Have you been back to Gatlinburg since?
When you did go back, did it seem like Gatlinburg was recovering?
Do you feel that some of the people you helped have been able to recover fincancially and rebuild their lives?
Did you ever see any of the friction amongst the community after the disaster?
Do you feel that people are making provisions for future disasters? Do you see this in any of the disasters you've served in?
How did the Gatlinburg deployment affect you mentally or spiritually?
Was there anything good or surprising that came out of this?

seo.title: Interview with Jeff Rouse, 2020-06-12 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
seo.description: Interview with Jeff Rouse, volunteer with Samaritan's Purse, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Rouse discusses his background with Samaritan's Purse before detailing the efforts of the organization in Gatlinburg after the wildfires. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "All of a sudden, one of the team members found this airplane, and it was just like finding a long lost piece of gold or something. It was just amazing that they were so excited because that was some memory of their dad."
